case_title: Mst. RAHAM BIBI vs AZMAT HAYAT KHATTAK, ADVOCATE

prosecution: Deputy Advocate-General for Government of N.-W.F.P.

complaint_summary: Mst. Raham Bibi alleged professional misconduct against her son and counsel, Azmat Hayat Khattak, for challenging a decree he had previously secured for her in a civil suit, violating professional ethics and trust.
investigation_summary: The Disciplinary Committee of the N.-W.F.P. Bar Council initiated proceedings, reviewed written statements, and adjourned the complaint sine die, leading to the appeal by Mst. Raham Bibi.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal found Azmat Hayat Khattak guilty of professional misconduct for violating ethical norms and betraying client trust. His suspension from the profession for five years was ordered, along with costs of Rs. 30,000.
punishment: Suspension from legal practice for five years and Rs. 30,000 in costs.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal accepted; respondent found guilty of professional misconduct.
legal_arguments: Respondent argued the appeal was incompetent due to procedural grounds under Section 41 of the Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973.
Appellant argued the respondent violated professional ethics by challenging a decree he had secured for her.
Tribunal ruled that professional misconduct includes actions with remote nexus to the matter and upheld the appellant's right to appeal.
statutes: Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973
witnesses: Asif Hamid Qureshi (Civil Judge 1st Class Kohat)

witness_statement.Amanullah Khan: Provided consent for decree in favor of appellant.
witness_statement.Asif Hamid Qureshi: Recorded statement on oath leading to decree.

maxims.Justice: Administer justice as it is near to piety.

legal_terms.Professional Misconduct: Violation of ethical norms by a legal practitioner.
legal_terms.Conflict of Interest: Representation of opposing interests by a counsel.

words_and_phrases.Sine Die: Adjournment without a specified date for resumption.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves professional misconduct by Azmat Hayat Khattak, who violated ethical norms by challenging a decree he had secured for his mother, Mst. Raham Bibi. The Tribunal ruled in favor of the appellant, suspending the respondent for five years and imposing costs.
